The fluorescent lights of Springfield General Hospital flickered with an almost rhythmic persistence, casting sickly shadows across the sterile corridors that Detective Edger knew all too well. She had walked these halls countless times as a child, visiting the nurses who had become surrogate mothers after the fire that claimed her parents. Now, twenty-three years later, she found herself returning under circumstances that made her stomach churn with a familiar dread.

The call had come at three in the morning, jolting her from restless dreams filled with smoke and screaming. Another nurse had been found, the fourth in as many weeks. Margaret Holloway, sixty-two, thirty years of dedicated service to the pediatric ward. Found in the supply closet with that same twisted grin carved into her face and her left index finger missing, severed with surgical precision.

Edger pushed through the double doors leading to the crime scene, her worn leather jacket creaking against the silence. The hospital at this hour felt like a tomb, populated only by the occasional shuffle of overnight staff and the steady beeping of life support machines in distant rooms. She had always hated hospitals, even before this case began consuming her every waking moment. The smell of disinfectant mixed with something darker, something that reminded her of death trying to hide behind cleanliness.

Crime scene tape cordoned off the supply closet where Margaret's body had been discovered. Officer Thompson, barely out of the academy, stood guard with a complexion that matched the hospital's white walls. "Detective, we haven't moved anything since the coroner finished. Same M.O. as the others."

Edger nodded, pulling on latex gloves that felt too much like the ones worn by the medical staff around them. She had studied the previous scenes until the images burned themselves into her retinas. Susan Martinez, found in the parking garage three weeks ago. Jennifer Park, discovered in the break room two weeks later. Sarah Chen, whose body had been arranged almost ceremonially in the hospital chapel just five days past. All nurses, all mutilated in identical fashion, all missing their left index fingers.

The closet was cramped, filled with towels and medical supplies that had been knocked aside to make room for Margaret's body. Edger crouched beside where the outline remained on the floor, her trained eye cataloging details that others might miss. No signs of struggle. No defensive wounds according to the preliminary examination. Each victim had been killed elsewhere and moved, positioned with an almost tender care that made the brutality seem even more obscene.

"Any witnesses this time?" she asked Thompson, though she already knew the answer. The killer had proven remarkably adept at avoiding detection, moving through the hospital like a ghost despite the security cameras positioned throughout the building.

"Nothing concrete. Night shift supervisor says she thought she heard someone crying around midnight, but when she went to check, the halls were empty. Could have been a patient or family member though."

Crying. That was new. Edger made a mental note as she examined the scene more closely. The previous murders had been conducted in complete silence, at least according to witness accounts. She pulled out her phone and snapped photographs from various angles, though she knew they would only add to the growing collection of images that haunted her apartment walls.

The forensics team had finished their preliminary work, but Edger had learned to trust her own observations above all else. Growing up in the system had taught her that adults often missed crucial details, too focused on their procedures and protocols to see what was right in front of them. She had solved her first case at age nine when she figured out which of her foster siblings had been stealing food from the communal kitchen. The same attention to detail that had kept her fed then now made her one of Springfield's most effective detectives.

As she examined the supply closet's contents, something caught her attention. A small piece of paper tucked behind a stack of surgical masks. Thompson hadn't noticed it, and the forensics team had apparently missed it as well. Edger carefully extracted the fragment with tweezers, her pulse quickening as she recognized handwriting.

"For Massimo," the note read in careful script. "The nurses took him away from me, and now they'll pay with more than their fingers."

Massimo. Finally, a name to attach to the killer's obsession. Edger felt the familiar rush that came with breaking through a case's outer shell, finding that first thread that might unravel the entire mystery. She sealed the note in an evidence bag and made her way toward the hospital's administrative offices.

Helen Kowalski had been the head of hospital administration for nearly four decades. If anyone would recognize the name Massimo in connection with the hospital's history, it would be her. Edger found the older woman in her office despite the early hour, surrounded by files and looking as though she hadn't slept in days.

"Detective Edger," Helen said, looking up with tired eyes. "I've been expecting you. Margaret was one of our best. This has to stop."

"I think I might have found something that could help." Edger showed her the note, watching Helen's expression carefully. "Does the name Massimo mean anything to you? Someone connected to the hospital, maybe a former patient?"

Helen's face went pale, her hands trembling slightly as she reached for a thick file cabinet behind her desk. "Massimo Torrino. I haven't heard that name in fifteen years, but I'll never forget it." She pulled out a manila folder, thick with medical records and incident reports. "He was a patient here when he was seven years old. Leukemia. We tried everything, but..."

"He died?"

"Yes, but not from the cancer. There was an incident." Helen's voice dropped to barely above a whisper. "His sister, Maria, she was seventeen at the time. Brilliant girl, wanted to be a doctor herself someday. She became convinced that the nursing staff wasn't giving Massimo proper care, that they were letting him suffer unnecessarily."

Edger felt pieces of the puzzle beginning to align in her mind. "What kind of incident?"

"Maria tried to remove Massimo from the hospital against medical advice. She believed she could care for him better at home. When the nurses tried to stop her, there was a struggle. Massimo was so weak from his treatments, and in the confusion..." Helen closed her eyes. "He fell down a flight of stairs. Broke his neck. Died instantly."

The crying that the night supervisor had heard suddenly made more sense. "What happened to Maria after that?"

"She disappeared. The police searched for weeks, but she vanished completely. Her parents said she blamed herself, blamed the hospital, blamed everyone. They moved away not long after the funeral."

Edger studied the photograph in the file. Maria Torrino at seventeen looked nothing like what she had expected. Small, delicate features, dark hair pulled back severely, eyes that seemed too old for her face. Not the imposing figure she had imagined when tracking a killer capable of overpowering trained medical professionals.

"Detective," Helen continued, "Maria would be thirty-two now, if she's still alive. But what you're suggesting, that she could be responsible for these murders... she was just a grieving child when I knew her."

"Grief can change people in ways we can't always predict." Edger had learned that lesson early in her career, watching how loss could transform ordinary individuals into something unrecognizable. "I'm going to need copies of everything you have on both Maria and Massimo Torrino."

As Helen prepared the documents, Edger's phone buzzed with a text message from the forensics lab. The results from the previous crime scenes had revealed something interesting about the missing fingers. They weren't just being collected as trophies. Chemical analysis suggested they were being preserved in some kind of acidic solution, most likely vinegar.

The implications sent a chill down Edger's spine. This wasn't just about revenge or twisted justice. The killer was keeping parts of the victims, treating them with the same clinical care that might be used to preserve medical specimens. It suggested a level of planning and psychological disturbance that went far beyond simple grief or anger.

Helen handed over the copied files, her expression grave. "Detective, if Maria is responsible for this, you have to understand that the girl I knew fifteen years ago wouldn't have been capable of such violence. Whatever she's become, whatever broke inside her when Massimo died, she needs help as much as she needs to be stopped."

Edger tucked the files under her arm and headed for the exit. She had heard similar pleas before, family members and friends insisting that the person they knew couldn't possibly be capable of the crimes under investigation. Sometimes they were right, and the real perpetrator was someone else entirely. But more often, they simply couldn't reconcile their memories with the reality of what grief and obsession could do to a human mind.

The drive back to the police station gave her time to process what she had learned. Maria Torrino, now thirty-two, had lost her younger brother in what she perceived as the hospital's negligence. The trauma had apparently festered for fifteen years, finally erupting into a calculated campaign of revenge against the nursing staff. But something still didn't fit properly in Edger's mental reconstruction of events.

The level of access required to move freely through the hospital suggested either extensive knowledge of the building's layout or help from someone on the inside. The precision of the killings indicated medical training or at least familiarity with human anatomy. Most troubling of all, the killer had managed to overpower four different women, ranging in age from twenty-eight to sixty-two, without leaving evidence of a struggle.

Back at her desk, Edger spread the Torrino files across every available surface and began constructing a timeline. Maria's academic records showed exceptional performance in biology and chemistry courses. Her younger brother's medical records painted a picture of a prolonged and painful battle with leukemia, complicated by infections and treatment side effects that had extended his suffering for months.

The incident report from Massimo's death made for difficult reading. According to witness statements, Maria had arrived at the hospital during evening visiting hours and demanded to take her brother home immediately. When staff explained that he was too ill to be moved, she had become increasingly agitated. The confrontation had escalated until Maria physically tried to carry Massimo from his bed.

Nurse Patricia Williams had been the first to intervene, followed by Jennifer Park and Sarah Chen. All three of the nurses who had tried to stop Maria that night were now dead, their fingers preserved like specimens in some grotesque collection. The connection was too strong to be coincidental.

Edger picked up her phone and dialed the number for Springfield General's security office. If Maria Torrino was somehow gaining access to the hospital, there had to be evidence of her presence somewhere in their surveillance system. The killings were too precise and well-timed to be the work of someone operating without inside knowledge.

Security chief Robert Martinez answered on the third ring. Edger had worked with him on previous cases and trusted his thoroughness. "Bob, I need you to pull surveillance footage going back four weeks. I'm looking for a woman, about thirty-two, dark hair, possibly using a false identity to gain access to the building."

"Already been through all the footage twice, Detective. No suspicious individuals, no unauthorized access. Whoever's doing this knows exactly how to avoid our cameras."

That confirmed Edger's suspicion that they were dealing with someone who had extensive knowledge of the hospital's security protocols. "What about staff access? Someone using stolen credentials or forged identification?"

"We've audited all employee badges. Nothing missing, no suspicious activity on any of the access logs."

Edger thanked Martinez and hung up, frustrated but not surprised. The killer had proven methodical in every other aspect of the crimes. It made sense that infiltrating the hospital's security would be handled with equal care.

She turned her attention to the note found at the latest crime scene. The handwriting analysis would take several days, but she could begin her own examination of the script and paper. The writing was careful, deliberate, with the kind of precise lettering that suggested either artistic training or medical education. The paper itself appeared to be standard notebook stock, nothing distinctive about the brand or quality.

More interesting was the phrasing: "The nurses took him away from me, and now they'll pay with more than their fingers." It suggested that the missing digits were just the beginning of the killer's plans. Edger had seen escalation patterns in serial cases before, where the perpetrator's violence increased over time as they became more confident or more desperate.

The preservation of the fingers in vinegar also indicated a level of ritualistic behavior that went beyond simple trophy collection. Vinegar had been used for centuries as a preservative, and its use suggested either historical knowledge or a deliberate choice to avoid modern chemical preservatives that might be traced back to a specific source.

As afternoon shadows began to lengthen across her desk, Edger realized she had been working for nearly twelve hours straight. The familiar ache in her shoulders reminded her of countless other cases that had consumed her attention to the exclusion of everything else. Her apartment would be empty and cold when she finally returned, filled with case files and takeout containers but little else that could be called a life.

The phone rang, interrupting her brooding. Officer Thompson's voice was tight with tension. "Detective, we've got another one."Edger's blood ran cold as Thompson's words sank in. "Where?" she asked, already reaching for her jacket.

"Same hospital, but this time it's different. The victim is still alive."

The drive to Springfield General felt like an eternity, though Edger's speedometer showed she was pushing well beyond the legal limit. Her mind raced through possibilities as she navigated the evening traffic. A surviving victim could provide the breakthrough they desperately needed, assuming the person was coherent enough to identify their attacker. The killer's pattern had been so methodical, so precise in its execution, that the idea of leaving someone alive seemed almost impossible to believe.

She arrived to find the hospital in controlled chaos. Additional security guards had been stationed at every entrance, and she could see Detective Morrison from the neighboring precinct coordinating with hospital administration in the main lobby. The presence of multiple agencies suggested that word of the latest incident had reached the higher levels of law enforcement, bringing with it the inevitable pressure to produce results quickly.

Thompson met her at the elevator, his earlier pallor replaced by an excited energy that made him appear even younger than his twenty-four years. "Victim's name is Linda Vasquez, she's a night shift nurse in the cardiac unit. Found unconscious in the stairwell about two hours ago, but she came around in the ambulance. She's been asking for you specifically."

That detail sent a chill through Edger's chest. None of the previous victims had survived long enough to speak with anyone, let alone request a specific detective by name. It suggested either that Linda Vasquez knew something crucial about the killer's identity, or that the killer had deliberately allowed her to survive in order to send some kind of message.

The elevator climbed slowly through the floors, each ding of the indicator seeming to echo in the confined space. Edger found herself studying Thompson's reflection in the polished metal doors, noting the way his hands trembled slightly despite his attempts to appear professional. She remembered feeling the same mixture of excitement and terror during her first major case, the intoxicating rush of being close to solving something important balanced against the very real fear of making a mistake that could cost lives.

The cardiac unit occupied the hospital's seventh floor, and as they emerged from the elevator, Edger could see that the entire area had been cordoned off with crime scene tape. Forensics teams moved through the corridors with their familiar methodical precision, photographing and cataloging every detail that might prove relevant to the investigation. The stairwell where Linda Vasquez had been found was accessible from multiple floors, providing numerous potential escape routes for someone familiar with the building's layout.

Dr. Sarah Kim, the attending physician overseeing Linda's care, met them outside the recovery room. Her expression was carefully neutral, but Edger could read the underlying tension in the set of her shoulders and the way she kept glancing toward the closed door behind her. Medical professionals were trained to maintain composure in crisis situations, but the recent string of murders had clearly shaken the hospital's entire staff.

"Detective Edger, your victim is stable but she's been through significant trauma," Dr. Kim began, her voice pitched low to avoid disturbing other patients. "She has a concussion, multiple contusions, and what appears to be a defensive wound on her left hand. The injury pattern suggests she fought back against her attacker, which might explain why she survived when the others didn't."

Edger absorbed this information while studying the doctor's face for additional details that might not make it into the official medical report. The presence of defensive wounds was encouraging, as it suggested that forensics might finally have physical evidence linking the killer to the crimes. Skin cells under fingernails, blood samples, or fabric fibers could provide the DNA evidence that had been frustratingly absent from the previous crime scenes.

"Has she been able to describe her attacker?" Edger asked.

"She's been somewhat incoherent, talking about someone she calls 'the angel of mercy.' She keeps insisting that the person who attacked her was trying to save someone named Massimo, and that she understands why the nurses had to die." Dr. Kim paused, clearly struggling with the implications of what she was reporting. "Detective, I have to tell you that some of what she's saying doesn't make complete sense. Head injuries can cause confusion and false memories, so you'll need to be careful about how much weight you give to her statements."

The mention of Massimo confirmed that Linda Vasquez had encountered the same killer responsible for the previous murders, but her apparent sympathy for the attacker's motivations was deeply disturbing. Edger had seen cases where victims developed psychological connections to their attackers, particularly in situations involving prolonged captivity or manipulation, but the phenomenon was unusual in what appeared to be a random assault.

Thompson opened the recovery room door carefully, and Edger got her first look at Linda Vasquez. The nurse appeared to be in her early forties, with graying hair and the kind of competent demeanor that suggested years of experience dealing with medical emergencies. The left side of her face was badly bruised, and her left hand was wrapped in surgical bandaging, but her eyes were alert and focused as Edger approached the bedside.

"Detective Edger," Linda said before any introductions could be made. "I knew you would come. She told me you would understand better than the others."

The use of feminine pronouns was the first concrete confirmation that they were looking for a woman, though Edger had suspected as much based on the crime scene evidence and psychological profile she had been developing. More concerning was Linda's suggestion that the attacker had specifically mentioned Edger by name, implying a level of personal interest that transformed the case from a series of random murders into something far more dangerous.

"Linda, I need you to tell me everything you remember about what happened tonight," Edger said, settling into the chair beside the hospital bed. "Start from the beginning, and don't worry if some details seem unclear. Head injuries can affect memory, so just share whatever you can recall."

Linda's eyes closed briefly, and when she opened them again, there was a clarity there that hadn't been present moments before. "I was doing my rounds around eleven-thirty, checking on the patients in rooms seven-oh-five through seven-fifteen. Mrs. Patterson in seven-oh-eight was having trouble sleeping, so I spent extra time with her, maybe twenty minutes. When I finally left her room, I noticed that someone had left one of the stairwell doors propped open."

She paused to accept a sip of water from the cup Thompson offered, her injured hand shaking slightly as she lifted it to her lips. The defensive wound Dr. Kim had mentioned was visible beneath the bandaging, and Edger could see what appeared to be bite marks along Linda's wrist and forearm.

"Hospital policy requires all stairwell doors to remain closed for security reasons," Linda continued. "So I went to investigate, thinking maybe someone from maintenance had forgotten to secure it properly. As soon as I stepped into the stairwell, I heard someone crying. Not sobbing, just this quiet, steady weeping that seemed to be coming from the floor below."

The crying again, just as the night supervisor had reported hearing around the time of Margaret Holloway's murder. Edger made a note to investigate whether similar sounds had been reported at the previous crime scenes, details that might have been dismissed as unimportant by witnesses who didn't understand their significance.

"I called out to ask if someone needed help," Linda said, her voice growing stronger as she continued the narrative. "The crying stopped immediately, and then I heard footsteps coming up the stairs toward me. I should have left right then, should have called security, but my training kicked in. Someone was obviously in distress, and I'm a nurse. Helping people is what I do."

Edger could see the self-recrimination in Linda's expression, the guilt that came from making a decision that had seemed reasonable at the time but had led to violence and trauma. She had interviewed countless victims who blamed themselves for the crimes committed against them, and she had learned to address those feelings directly rather than allowing them to interfere with the investigation.

"You responded exactly as you were trained to do," Edger said firmly. "What happened to you is not your fault. The person who attacked you is the only one responsible for those choices."

Linda nodded gratefully and continued her account. "A woman appeared on the landing below me, maybe in her early thirties, average height, dark hair pulled back in a ponytail. She was wearing scrubs, the kind our nursing staff uses, but I didn't recognize her face. She looked up at me and said, 'You're Linda Vasquez. You worked with Jennifer Park.'"

The killer's knowledge of the hospital staff relationships suggested either extensive surveillance or access to personnel records. Jennifer Park had been the second victim, found in the break room two weeks earlier, and her connection to Linda Vasquez implied that the murders were not random selections but carefully chosen targets based on specific criteria that the killer had established.

"What did you say to her?" Edger asked.

"I told her that yes, Jennifer and I had worked together, and I asked if she was a friend of Jennifer's family. She started walking up the stairs toward me, very slowly, and she said, 'Jennifer was there the night they killed Massimo. You were there too, weren't you, Linda? You were all there when my little brother died.'"

The pieces of the puzzle were finally beginning to align in a way that confirmed Edger's working theory about the killer's identity. Maria Torrino had apparently maintained detailed knowledge of which hospital staff members had been present during the incident that led to her brother's death fifteen years earlier. The systematic targeting of those specific individuals represented a level of planning and psychological obsession that had been building for over a decade.

"Did you remember being involved in an incident with a patient named Massimo?" Edger asked.

Linda's expression grew thoughtful, and she stared at the ceiling for several moments before responding. "Fifteen years ago, I was still relatively new to the hospital. I worked primarily in pediatrics back then, before transferring to cardiac care. There was a situation with a young boy, a leukemia patient whose sister tried to remove him from the hospital against medical advice. Several of us had to intervene when she became physically aggressive."

She paused again, and Edger could see the memories beginning to coalesce in Linda's mind as she connected past events to her recent attack. The realization that she had been targeted for something that had happened when she was barely out of nursing school was clearly disturbing, but it also provided crucial context for understanding the killer's motivations.

"The sister was just a teenager, maybe seventeen or eighteen years old," Linda continued. "She was convinced that we weren't taking proper care of her brother, that we were letting him suffer unnecessarily. She kept saying that she could provide better care at home, that hospitals were places where people went to die. We tried to explain that moving him would be dangerous, but she wouldn't listen."

Thompson had been taking notes throughout the interview, but Edger noticed that his writing had become increasingly erratic as Linda's account progressed. The revelation that the current murders were connected to an incident from fifteen years earlier was clearly overwhelming for someone with his limited experience, and she made a mental note to spend time later helping him process the psychological complexity of the case.

"What happened when you tried to stop her from taking the boy?" Edger asked.

"There was a struggle. The sister was small, but she was desperate, and desperation can give people incredible strength. Jennifer Park tried to block the doorway while Sarah Chen called security. I attempted to keep the boy calm and prevent him from being injured during the confrontation." Linda's voice dropped to barely above a whisper. "But he was so weak from his treatments, and when his sister tried to carry him, she stumbled. They both fell, and the boy hit his head on the doorframe. He died before the paramedics could arrive."

The guilt in Linda's voice was unmistakable, the burden of a tragedy that she had carried for fifteen years without fully understanding how it would eventually return to haunt her. Edger could see why the incident had affected Maria Torrino so profoundly, transforming a grieving teenager into someone capable of methodical, calculated murder.

"Linda, I need you to focus on what happened tonight. After the woman identified herself as Massimo's sister, what did she do?"

"She continued walking up the stairs, but her demeanor completely changed. The sadness I had heard in her crying was replaced by something cold and clinical. She reached into her pocket and pulled out a surgical scalpel, one of the disposable ones we use in the emergency room. She said, 'I've been watching all of you for months, learning your schedules, understanding your routines. You killed my brother, and now you're going to pay the same price as the others.'"

The mention of months of surveillance explained how the killer had been able to avoid security cameras and move through the hospital undetected. Extensive observation of the staff's patterns would have allowed her to identify the optimal times and locations for each attack, minimizing the risk of interruption or capture.**Chapter 2**

"She came at me with the scalpel, moving faster than I expected," Linda continued, her voice steadying as she relived the confrontation. "I managed to grab her wrist with my left hand, which is how I got cut, but she was stronger than she looked. We struggled for maybe thirty seconds before she managed to break free. Instead of continuing the attack, she stepped back and stared at me with this strange expression, almost like she was confused about something."

Edger leaned forward, sensing that this might be the crucial detail that explained why Linda had survived when the others had not. The killer's behavioral pattern had been remarkably consistent across the previous murders, suggesting a level of psychological rigidity that would make any deviation significant. If Maria Torrino had deliberately chosen to spare Linda's life, there had to be a specific reason that fit within her distorted understanding of justice and revenge.

"What did she say when she stepped back?" Edger asked.

"She looked at the blood on the scalpel, then at my injured hand, and she said, 'You tried to help him, didn't you? That night when he fell, you were the one who tried to stop the bleeding.' I told her that yes, I had attempted to provide medical assistance, and she nodded like that confirmed something important in her mind." Linda paused to take another sip of water, clearly struggling with the memory of the encounter. "Then she said something that I still don't understand: 'Detective Edger will want to know that the collection is almost complete. Tell her that Massimo will have justice, but mercy still exists for those who showed him kindness.'"

The killer's message was clearly intended for Edger specifically, confirming her growing suspicion that Maria Torrino had been monitoring the investigation and developing some kind of personal fixation on the detective assigned to the case. The reference to a "collection" suggested that the preserved fingers were being gathered for some specific purpose, possibly as part of a ritualistic conclusion to the killing spree that would involve Massimo's memory in some twisted way.

Thompson looked up from his notepad with an expression of barely controlled anxiety. "Detective, if she's been watching the investigation, doesn't that mean she might know where you live, what your daily routine looks like?"

The question had already occurred to Edger, and the implications were deeply unsettling. Serial killers who developed personal obsessions with the investigators pursuing them represented a significant escalation in terms of both psychological instability and potential danger. She would need to take precautions for her own safety while continuing to pursue the case, a balancing act that could compromise her effectiveness if she allowed fear to influence her decision-making.

"Linda, I need you to think carefully about the woman's appearance," Edger said, choosing to focus on actionable intelligence rather than dwelling on her personal vulnerability. "You mentioned that she was wearing hospital scrubs. Did they look authentic, like official hospital issue, or could they have been purchased elsewhere?"

"They looked exactly like ours, down to the Springfield General logo embroidered on the chest pocket. Either she stole them from somewhere in the hospital, or she had them specially made to match our uniforms." Linda's brow furrowed as she concentrated on the memory. "But there was something else that seemed off about her appearance. Her hands were stained yellow, like she had been working with some kind of chemical solution. The smell was sharp and acidic, almost like vinegar but with something else mixed in."

The yellow staining confirmed Edger's suspicion about how the killer was preserving the severed fingers. Prolonged exposure to acidic solutions would indeed cause that kind of discoloration, and the smell Linda described suggested a mixture of vinegar with possibly formaldehyde or another preservative agent. The killer's knowledge of preservation techniques indicated either medical training or extensive self-education in anatomical procedures.

Dr. Kim appeared in the doorway, her expression suggesting that visiting hours were approaching their limit. Head injury patients required rest for proper recovery, and Edger knew that pushing Linda too hard could compromise both her health and the reliability of her statements. At the same time, every hour that passed gave Maria Torrino additional opportunities to plan her next attack or potentially disappear entirely.

"Just a few more questions," Edger said to Dr. Kim before turning back to Linda. "After she gave you the message for me, what did she do?"

"She walked back down the stairs, but before she disappeared, she turned around and said, 'The nurses who showed mercy will be spared, but the collection must be completed. There are still three more who must pay for what they did to Massimo.' Then I heard a door open and close somewhere below, and she was gone. I tried to follow her, but the head injury made me dizzy, and I collapsed in the stairwell where security found me."

Three more targets. Edger felt the familiar weight of responsibility settle across her shoulders as she realized that Maria Torrino's killing spree was far from over. The systematic nature of the attacks suggested that the remaining victims had already been identified and were probably under surveillance, their daily routines being studied and their vulnerabilities assessed. Time was running out to prevent additional murders, and the killer's personal interest in Edger added a layer of psychological complexity that could either provide an advantage or prove to be a fatal distraction.

Thompson closed his notepad and followed Edger into the hallway, where they could speak without disturbing Linda's recovery. His earlier excitement had been replaced by the sobering realization of how much work remained ahead of them, and Edger could see him struggling to process the full implications of what they had learned. The transition from textbook criminology to real-world investigation was always jarring, particularly when dealing with cases that involved such intimate violence and psychological deterioration.

"What's our next move?" Thompson asked, his voice betraying the uncertainty that came with inexperience.

"We need to identify the three remaining targets and get them into protective custody before Maria Torrino can reach them," Edger replied, already mentally reviewing the personnel files Helen Kowalski had provided earlier. "Based on Linda's account and the pattern of previous murders, we're looking for hospital staff members who were present during the incident fifteen years ago but who Maria doesn't perceive as having shown kindness to her brother."

The elevator carried them back to the main floor, where Detective Morrison was still coordinating with hospital administration. His presence represented both additional resources and increased bureaucratic complexity, as multiple agencies working the same case often struggled with communication and jurisdiction issues. Edger had learned to navigate these political waters carefully, sharing enough information to maintain cooperation while retaining enough control to pursue her own investigative instincts.

Morrison approached as soon as he saw them emerge from the elevator, his expression indicating that he had been briefed on the basic details of Linda Vasquez's attack. At fifty-three, he had the kind of seasoned competence that came from decades of police work, but Edger also knew that his methodology tended toward conventional approaches that might not be effective against someone as psychologically complex as Maria Torrino.

"Edger, I've been coordinating with hospital security to review all personnel records from fifteen years ago," Morrison said, pulling out a tablet computer loaded with digital files. "We've identified seven staff members who were present during the incident involving Massimo Torrino, four of whom are now dead. That leaves three potential targets, assuming your killer is working from the same list."

The efficiency was impressive, but Edger wondered if the bureaucratic approach would be sufficient to predict Maria Torrino's next moves. The killer had demonstrated remarkable adaptability and psychological sophistication, qualities that suggested she might not be following a simple checklist approach to selecting her victims. The distinction she had made between nurses who showed mercy and those who deserved punishment indicated a level of moral reasoning that could lead to unexpected decisions.

"Who are the three remaining staff members?" Edger asked.

Morrison consulted his tablet and read from the screen. "Patricia Williams, now head of pediatric nursing, sixty-one years old. Michael Chen, brother of victim Sarah Chen, currently works in the emergency room, thirty-four years old. And Dr. Elizabeth Harper, who was a resident at the time but is now chief of pediatric oncology, forty-two years old."

The inclusion of Michael Chen was particularly troubling, as his relationship to one of the previous victims suggested that Maria Torrino's definition of justice extended beyond the specific individuals who had been present during her brother's death. Family members of the medical staff were apparently considered legitimate targets, a expansion of the killing pattern that could potentially involve dozens of additional people connected to the hospital.

"We need to get all three of them into protective custody immediately," Edger said. "Based on the timeline of previous attacks, Maria probably has surveillance schedules established for each of them. If we can disrupt her planning by removing the targets from their normal routines, we might be able to force her into making a mistake."

Morrison nodded and began making phone calls to arrange for police protection, but Edger found herself thinking about the personal message Maria had sent through Linda Vasquez. The killer's interest in communicating directly with the detective assigned to her case suggested a level of ego involvement that went beyond simple revenge against the hospital staff. Serial killers who developed relationships with their pursuers often did so because they craved recognition for their intelligence and planning abilities, a psychological vulnerability that could potentially be exploited.

Thompson had been quiet during the exchange with Morrison, but as they walked toward the hospital's main exit, he voiced a concern that had clearly been troubling him. "Detective, what if Maria Torrino doesn't stick to her original target list? If she's been watching the investigation and developing some kind of personal interest in you, couldn't she decide to expand her definition of who deserves punishment?"

While the defendant's mental illness may explain her actions, it cannot excuse the choice to pursue revenge through violence rather than seeking appropriate help through legitimate channels."

Detective Edger attended the sentencing hearing, bringing a sense of closure to her involvement in a case that had challenged her understanding of criminal motivation and the relationship between trauma and violence. The experience had demonstrated the importance of early intervention for individuals dealing with severe trauma, as well as the need for law enforcement officers to understand the psychological factors that could transform grief and loss into something far more dangerous and destructive.

As she left the courthouse following the sentencing, Edger found herself thinking about seven-year-old Massimo Torrino, whose death from childhood leukemia had set in motion the events that had consumed so many lives fifteen years later. The boy had been an innocent victim of a terrible disease, but his memory had been transformed by his sister's inability to process her loss into a symbol of injustice that demanded violent retribution. The fluorescent lights of Springfield General Hospital flickered with an almost rhythmic persistence, casting sickly shadows across the sterile corridors that Detective Edger knew all too well. She had walked these halls countless times as a child, visiting the nurses who had become surrogate mothers after the fire that claimed her parents. Now, twenty-three years later, she found herself returning under circumstances that made her stomach churn with a familiar dread.

The call had come at three in the morning, jolting her from restless dreams filled with smoke and screaming. Another nurse had been found, the fourth in as many weeks. Margaret Holloway, sixty-two, thirty years of dedicated service to the pediatric ward. Found in the supply closet with that same twisted grin carved into her face and her left index finger missing, severed with surgical precision.

Edger pushed through the double doors leading to the crime scene, her worn leather jacket creaking against the silence. The hospital at this hour felt like a tomb, populated only by the occasional shuffle of overnight staff and the steady beeping of life support machines in distant rooms. She had always hated hospitals, even before this case began consuming her every waking moment. The smell of disinfectant mixed with something darker, something that reminded her of death trying to hide behind cleanliness.

Crime scene tape cordoned off the supply closet where Margaret's body had been discovered. Officer Thompson, barely out of the academy, stood guard with a complexion that matched the hospital's white walls. "Detective, we haven't moved anything since the coroner finished. Same M.O. as the others."

Edger nodded, pulling on latex gloves that felt too much like the ones worn by the medical staff around them. She had studied the previous scenes until the images burned themselves into her retinas. Susan Martinez, found in the parking garage three weeks ago. Jennifer Park, discovered in the break room two weeks later. Sarah Chen, whose body had been arranged almost ceremonially in the hospital chapel just five days past. All nurses, all mutilated in identical fashion, all missing their left index fingers.

The closet was cramped, filled with towels and medical supplies that had been knocked aside to make room for Margaret's body. Edger crouched beside where the outline remained on the floor, her trained eye cataloging details that others might miss. No signs of struggle. No defensive wounds according to the preliminary examination. Each victim had been killed elsewhere and moved, positioned with an almost tender care that made the brutality seem even more obscene.

"Any witnesses this time?" she asked Thompson, though she already knew the answer. The killer had proven remarkably adept at avoiding detection, moving through the hospital like a ghost despite the security cameras positioned throughout the building.

"Nothing concrete. Night shift supervisor says she thought she heard someone crying around midnight, but when she went to check, the halls were empty. Could have been a patient or family member though."

Crying. That was new. Edger made a mental note as she examined the scene more closely. The previous murders had been conducted in complete silence, at least according to witness accounts. She pulled out her phone and snapped photographs from various angles, though she knew they would only add to the growing collection of images that haunted her apartment walls.

The forensics team had finished their preliminary work, but Edger had learned to trust her own observations above all else. Growing up in the system had taught her that adults often missed crucial details, too focused on their procedures and protocols to see what was right in front of them. She had solved her first case at age nine when she figured out which of her foster siblings had been stealing food from the communal kitchen. The same attention to detail that had kept her fed then now made her one of Springfield's most effective detectives.

As she examined the supply closet's contents, something caught her attention. A small piece of paper tucked behind a stack of surgical masks. Thompson hadn't noticed it, and the forensics team had apparently missed it as well. Edger carefully extracted the fragment with tweezers, her pulse quickening as she recognized handwriting.

"For Massimo," the note read in careful script. "The nurses took him away from me, and now they'll pay with more than their fingers."

Massimo. Finally, a name to attach to the killer's obsession. Edger felt the familiar rush that came with breaking through a case's outer shell, finding that first thread that might unravel the entire mystery. She sealed the note in an evidence bag and made her way toward the hospital's administrative offices.

Helen Kowalski had been the head of hospital administration for nearly four decades. If anyone would recognize the name Massimo in connection with the hospital's history, it would be her. Edger found the older woman in her office despite the early hour, surrounded by files and looking as though she hadn't slept in days.

"Detective Edger," Helen said, looking up with tired eyes. "I've been expecting you. Margaret was one of our best. This has to stop."

"I think I might have found something that could help." Edger showed her the note, watching Helen's expression carefully. "Does the name Massimo mean anything to you? Someone connected to the hospital, maybe a former patient?"

Helen's face went pale, her hands trembling slightly as she reached for a thick file cabinet behind her desk. "Massimo Torrino. I haven't heard that name in fifteen years, but I'll never forget it." She pulled out a manila folder, thick with medical records and incident reports. "He was a patient here when he was seven years old. Leukemia. We tried everything, but..."

"He died?"

"Yes, but not from the cancer. There was an incident." Helen's voice dropped to barely above a whisper. "His sister, Maria, she was seventeen at the time. Brilliant girl, wanted to be a doctor herself someday. She became convinced that the nursing staff wasn't giving Massimo proper care, that they were letting him suffer unnecessarily."

Edger felt pieces of the puzzle beginning to align in her mind. "What kind of incident?"

"Maria tried to remove Massimo from the hospital against medical advice. She believed she could care for him better at home. When the nurses tried to stop her, there was a struggle. Massimo was so weak from his treatments, and in the confusion..." Helen closed her eyes. "He fell down a flight of stairs. Broke his neck. Died instantly."

The crying that the night supervisor had heard suddenly made more sense. "What happened to Maria after that?"

"She disappeared. The police searched for weeks, but she vanished completely. Her parents said she blamed herself, blamed the hospital, blamed everyone. They moved away not long after the funeral."

Edger studied the photograph in the file. Maria Torrino at seventeen looked nothing like what she had expected. Small, delicate features, dark hair pulled back severely, eyes that seemed too old for her face. Not the imposing figure she had imagined when tracking a killer capable of overpowering trained medical professionals.

"Detective," Helen continued, "Maria would be thirty-two now, if she's still alive. But what you're suggesting, that she could be responsible for these murders... she was just a grieving child when I knew her."

"Grief can change people in ways we can't always predict." Edger had learned that lesson early in her career, watching how loss could transform ordinary individuals into something unrecognizable. "I'm going to need copies of everything you have on both Maria and Massimo Torrino."

As Helen prepared the documents, Edger's phone buzzed with a text message from the forensics lab. The results from the previous crime scenes had revealed something interesting about the missing fingers. They weren't just being collected as trophies. Chemical analysis suggested they were being preserved in some kind of acidic solution, most likely vinegar.

The implications sent a chill down Edger's spine. This wasn't just about revenge or twisted justice. The killer was keeping parts of the victims, treating them with the same clinical care that might be used to preserve medical specimens. It suggested a level of planning and psychological disturbance that went far beyond simple grief or anger.

Helen handed over the copied files, her expression grave. "Detective, if Maria is responsible for this, you have to understand that the girl I knew fifteen years ago wouldn't have been capable of such violence. Whatever she's become, whatever broke inside her when Massimo died, she needs help as much as she needs to be stopped."

Edger tucked the files under her arm and headed for the exit. She had heard similar pleas before, family members and friends insisting that the person they knew couldn't possibly be capable of the crimes under investigation. Sometimes they were right, and the real perpetrator was someone else entirely. But more often, they simply couldn't reconcile their memories with the reality of what grief and obsession could do to a human mind.

The drive back to the police station gave her time to process what she had learned. Maria Torrino, now thirty-two, had lost her younger brother in what she perceived as the hospital's negligence. The trauma had apparently festered for fifteen years, finally erupting into a calculated campaign of revenge against the nursing staff. But something still didn't fit properly in Edger's mental reconstruction of events.

The level of access required to move freely through the hospital suggested either extensive knowledge of the building's layout or help from someone on the inside. The precision of the killings indicated medical training or at least familiarity with human anatomy. Most troubling of all, the killer had managed to overpower four different women, ranging in age from twenty-eight to sixty-two, without leaving evidence of a struggle.

Back at her desk, Edger spread the Torrino files across every available surface and began constructing a timeline. Maria's academic records showed exceptional performance in biology and chemistry courses. Her younger brother's medical records painted a picture of a prolonged and painful battle with leukemia, complicated by infections and treatment side effects that had extended his suffering for months.

The incident report from Massimo's death made for difficult reading. According to witness statements, Maria had arrived at the hospital during evening visiting hours and demanded to take her brother home immediately. When staff explained that he was too ill to be moved, she had become increasingly agitated. The confrontation had escalated until Maria physically tried to carry Massimo from his bed.

Nurse Patricia Williams had been the first to intervene, followed by Jennifer Park and Sarah Chen. All three of the nurses who had tried to stop Maria that night were now dead, their fingers preserved like specimens in some grotesque collection. The connection was too strong to be coincidental.

Edger picked up her phone and dialed the number for Springfield General's security office. If Maria Torrino was somehow gaining access to the hospital, there had to be evidence of her presence somewhere in their surveillance system. The killings were too precise and well-timed to be the work of someone operating without inside knowledge.

Security chief Robert Martinez answered on the third ring. Edger had worked with him on previous cases and trusted his thoroughness. "Bob, I need you to pull surveillance footage going back four weeks. I'm looking for a woman, about thirty-two, dark hair, possibly using a false identity to gain access to the building."

"Already been through all the footage twice, Detective. No suspicious individuals, no unauthorized access. Whoever's doing this knows exactly how to avoid our cameras."

That confirmed Edger's suspicion that they were dealing with someone who had extensive knowledge of the hospital's security protocols. "What about staff access? Someone using stolen credentials or forged identification?"

"We've audited all employee badges. Nothing missing, no suspicious activity on any of the access logs."

Edger thanked Martinez and hung up, frustrated but not surprised. The killer had proven methodical in every other aspect of the crimes. It made sense that infiltrating the hospital's security would be handled with equal care.

She turned her attention to the note found at the latest crime scene. The handwriting analysis would take several days, but she could begin her own examination of the script and paper. The writing was careful, deliberate, with the kind of precise lettering that suggested either artistic training or medical education. The paper itself appeared to be standard notebook stock, nothing distinctive about the brand or quality.

More interesting was the phrasing: "The nurses took him away from me, and now they'll pay with more than their fingers." It suggested that the missing digits were just the beginning of the killer's plans. Edger had seen escalation patterns in serial cases before, where the perpetrator's violence increased over time as they became more confident or more desperate.

The preservation of the fingers in vinegar also indicated a level of ritualistic behavior that went beyond simple trophy collection. Vinegar had been used for centuries as a preservative, and its use suggested either historical knowledge or a deliberate choice to avoid modern chemical preservatives that might be traced back to a specific source.

As afternoon shadows began to lengthen across her desk, Edger realized she had been working for nearly twelve hours straight.
